title.narrative: SWE-2012-131: The Gendered Political Economies of Coca versus Cocaine in Chapare, Bolivia
SWE-2012-131: The Gendered Political Economies of Coca versus Cocaine in Chapare, Bolivia

description.narrative: This project explores local understandings of the radically higher degree of transfer of surplus value from peasant families through illicit versus licit commercialization of coca and the gendered dimension of this difference, visible in the fact that coca crops sold as raw material for illegal drugs production are commercialized by the men in peasant families, whereas coca crops sold licitly are marketed by the women. Through field research in Chapare, the project explores if the meanings of the difference can be constructed as a reason for abandoning illicit commercialization of coca in favor of licit commercialization, and whether its gendered dimension can be constructed, among local women, as a motive to use their entrepreneurship as a means for increasing the proportion of coca grown by the family which is commercialized licitly.
